Neil Henshall I also remember the high level of public scrutiny that followed the Expenses Scandal, and the new rules that were imposed, such as all MPs having to publish their expenses, and reductions in what they were allowed to claim. When it comes down to it, we demand high standards from our parliamentarians. 

The House of Lords is an ongoing puzzle. But their power has been significantly diminished over the years, they have little real power, other than to send bills back for 'suggested' amendments; the real power lies with the legitimately elected House of Commons. 

Further reform to the Lords is inevitable. 

Also, the UK joined the EEC, a trading group. The decision to create the EU (1992), and develop it further in following treaties has always been controversial, not just in the U.K, but many other countries across Europe... this is shown when France, Ireland, Netherlands, et al., were asked to vote, then asked to vote again when they showed they didn't agree. 

If the EU is to gain public support, it needs to become much more open, and much more democratic... I truly believe if the most Eurosceptic country (UK), had voted to stay, any possible change could never happen.... at least it now still has a chance.

Frank, well, having a degree in eu and uk constitutional law, having worked in Brussels for an NGO petitioning to make laws (civil society group, so the ethical kind of lobbying) and reporting on EU regulations on a regular basis....

<cracks knuckles>

So here's how it happens. The commission is approached by civil society or industry groups saying that x is a problem. Let's say it's railway signalling systems for the sake of this example.

They say it's expensive and cumbersome and inhibits cross border trade and transport to have 50 signalling systems in 27 member states. The commission commissions a study into whether there is a problem (study is usually around €30k). There is. They go to the parliament and say they want to look at it, the parliament (filled with elected officials) and they vote on whether to do something about it.

So they do. They send the commission away with a budget (now about €50k) to come up with a solution. They consult with national and international experts and come up with something called ERTMS which is terribly clever and will save a lot of accidents as well as time and money. Rail is also the most environmentally sustainable of all freight transports so it's good for the environment too. 

So they go to the parliament and say they've got this solution and they want to roll it out across Europe. The parliament votes and says yes. It goes up to the council of Europe (made up of transport ministers of all member states) who agree (either by consensus or majority) that they'd like to make rail transport safer, cheaper, easier and more economical, and so they tell the commission to write a four line directive saying that the signalling system should be rolled out on cardinal routes (TEN-T network) across Europe. 

They allocate a fund to help member states with it, who then transpose it into national law (usually a more lengthy document than the original directive) and then, hey presto, ten years later, rail transport is safer and the Europeans (including the British) are making the safest trains and railways in the world, creating an international standard and it's all terribly innovative and profitable.

Ok Naomi Boyden, Here is something for you to journalisticaly research. The Uk has never legally been a member of the EU. In 1973 the then Lord Chancellor,Lord Kilmuir advised the Heath Government that to sign the Treaty of Rome would be an act of Treason and sedition under the 1351 Treason act. Also Treason under the 1559 Act of Supremacy. Also Treason under the1688/9 Declaration and Bill of Rights. Heath signed that Treaty and thus carried out an act of Treason, by ceding power to other countries. Each successive Government is guilty of Treason for continuing with this illegal Treaty. Unless the Treason acts have been repealed that is still the case. Unfortunately i have not the finances to pursue this, my BSc. carries no wealth.

In response the European Union brought in measures which restricted anglers to fishing for bass on a catch and release basis only for the first six months of 2016, and allowing anglers to retain one bass per day for the second half of the year. There were also limits placed on commercial fishing, although the gill net fishery had its bass quota increased, much to the anger of recreational anglers. The future of bass in Europe’s waters in one of the most important issues in sea fishing at the moment, with ICES (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea) – a powerful organisation which advises the EU on quotas and conservation issues – recommending a total ban on all forms of bass fishing (recreational and commercial) in 2017. In the end this did not happen and instead anglers had the same restrictions placed on them in 2017 (catch and release only for the first half of the year and one bass per angler per day for the rest of the year.) The vast majority of commercial fishing vessels are banned from specifically targeting bass in 2017, although they are able to retain generous levels of bass bycatch.

Michael Baker No I was asked repeatedly what I didn't like about EU law. :-) People still banging on about that... I voted to leave the EU for lots of reasons. I believe uncontrolled EU immigration is putting stress on our housing/health/education/police and jobs in a time where those services are being cut and not invested in to cater for the increased numbers of people needing those services. I voted to leave because of the atrocious way the EU dealt with Turkey over the refugee crisis, clearly despite all noises to the contrary angling towards Turkey eventually joining the EU (which might be a positive step for the right reasons but it won't be). I voted to leave because of the failings of the CAP and the CFP. I voted to leave because of the failings of the ECB and the all stick approach to any EU member who happens to fall foul of it (Greece latest big example but there are others). I voted to leave because as flawed as it is, at least a national government is controlled by the party system, and I can hope to vote out a party taking the country in a direction I don't like and therefore effect change. I voted to leave because of the enormous waste in EU government. I voted to leave because I believe the EU is probably doomed to failure and better to leave early to avoid the rush.

The EU has done lots of good. No argument from me there. It may well continue to do a lot of good too. But it's done a lot of ill as well. People ignore that. As a stabilizing force in Europe it's had reasonable success (but try having that conversation with a Yugoslavian or a Cypriot). People like the status quo so I completely understand the better the devil you know approach. I prefer better no devil at all. Of course that means leaving the EU leaves us with the Tories... Ideally not for long. People are far too short termist in their views.
Sadly that didn't make a catchy soundbyte for the leave campaign or they might have won by a bit more than 4% :-)

The EU is wasteful. Vast sums of money have been spent on unnecessary and inappropriate projects such as £760,000 for a gender equal cultural centre which was never built, over £350,000 for a project to get European children to draw each other and £155,000 for a Portuguese golf resort. Of course, the UK government too wastes money but why subject ourselves to more waste than we have to, particularly in the age of austerity?  The UK does not need the EU to be relevant on the world stage - Supporters of the EU often argue that we must remain in it to stay relevant but much of our clout does not come from our membership of the EU. We are one of only 5 permanent members of the UN Security Council, we are members of the world's most powerful military alliance in NATO and we are key players in the IMF and the World Bank. On the other hand, the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy is toothless and requires unanimity before new policy stances can be adopted. The EU is credible because states like the UK and Germany are members, not the other way around.

For goodness sake, the vote wasn't about whether to Leave the EU or not,  it was on the terms of the proposals. May has said that if either the EU or Parliament voted against her proposals she was leaving anyway but would follow WTO rulings ... No further negotiations. It's highly unlikely that the EU will agree to her proposals anyway so When Brexit is the disaster that most experts are predicting you can guarantee she'll blame the EU for not giving her a "fair deal". Had parliament voted against the proposals she would have blamed them saying " if you had agreed to my proposals we could have got a better deal and made it work".
